1.heading: Humane Society.
1.title: "I Have It All Sent to the Humane Society"
1.author: by Mark Buford.
notes: Summary: The author of this dog owner's guide (Brewster) isn't making any money on it.

2.heading: Humane Society.
2.title: "I Sense That We have Something in Common"
2.author: Guisewite.
notes: Summary: Electra tries to radiate calm and coolness from the Humane Society cage, then knocks Cathy over and licks her face.

3.heading: Humane Society.
3.title: "Will Someone Please Call the Humane Society?"
3.author: K McC.
notes: Summary: The golfer figures out the bill for 18 holes of caddying; Tommy owes three dollars.

5.title: Humanism, Race, and Historical Voices in Superhero Comics
5.author: Aldo J
notes: The draft of a conference paper.

6.heading: Humanitarians.
6.title: "Count Leo Tolstoy : Russia's Writer-Humanitarian" 3 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 14
6.author: [No author]
notes: "Russia's famous writer and humanitarian is an inspiration to the fighting men and women of his country, who understand the noble ideas he championed, and feel a kinship with him!"

12.heading: Humanity.
12.title: "Special Agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation". 5 p. in True Comics, no. 34
12.author: [No author]
notes: (7th story; pages 26-30 of magazine; mentioned on cover)

SUMMARY: FBI Agent Steve Saunders solves a case of sabotage: an arsonist/saboteur is burning railroad bridges for revenge against humanity, and he hasn't registered for the draft, either. 1. United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation. k. Sabotage. k. Arson. k. Railroad bridges. k. Bridges. k. Revenge. k. Humanity. k. Registration. k. The draft. Call no.: PN6728.1.P3T7no.34

13.heading: Humanity.
13.title: "'Taint the Meat, It's the Humanity!"
13.author: Jack Davis
13.appears_in: p. 36-44 in Those Were the Terrible, Shocking, Sensational, Appalling, Forbidden, But Simply Wonderful Horror Comics of the 1950's (New York : Nostalgia Press, 1971).
notes: Reprinted from Tales from the Crypt, no. 32 (Oct./Nov. 1952).
Involves a butcher and black-market meat.

14.title: Humanity. "Theodore Sturgeon's More than Human"
14.author: Douglas Moench and Alex Niño
14.appears_in: p. 37-46 in Heavy Metal, v. 3 [i.e., v. 2], no. 2 (June 1978).

15.heading: Humanity.
15.title: "There Were Times I Was Sure Lucky Pilots went Down with their Planes"
15.author: Saunders and Giella.
notes: Summary: The North Vietnamese kept American airmen in cages, saying they were guilty of crimes against humanity.

16.heading: Humanity.
16.title: Walt Disney presents The Little Mermaid
16.author: adapted by Stephanie Calmenson ; illustrated by Franc Mateu.
notes: Summary: A sea princess, longing to be human, trades her tail for legs, hoping to win the heart of the prince.

17.heading: Humanity.
17.title: Walt Disney's Classic the Little Mermaid
17.author: based on Disney's full-length animated movie ; adapted by Jan Carr.
notes: Summary: Ariel is a beautiful mermaid who longs to be human. Her father, King Triton, has always told her that humans are bad, and he is angry when she falls in love with a handsome human prince named Eric. In order to win the Prince, Ariel makes a bargain with the evil sea witch Ursula and her slimy eels, Flotsam and Jetsam. They will make her human, but she must give up her voice. She then has three days to get Eric to kiss her, or she will turn back into a mermaid.

18.heading: Humanity.
18.title: "The Wish"
18.author: editor, Geo
18.appears_in: Wildman ; writer, Nicola Cuti ; artist, John Byrne. 7 p. in The Complete Rog 2000 (July 1982)

French comics. 2. Tibet
